subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Big Mistake!
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-835248760-1262464509=:20888
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I don't think "Objective" means what you think it means.

But the point of =
the test it to find a method that will allow the evidence to speak for itse=
lf, and that is not subject to, well, subjective interpretation.=C2=A0 I'm =
sure if you were involved in the testing design, that could be achieved, to=
 keep the results from being biased, and to keep everyone 'honest, as you p=
ut it.

You also said below " If a person doesn't want to hear it, they won=
't".=C2=A0 Yes, this could be a problem with the test, unless a good test i=
s developed, to remove that subjectivity.=C2=A0 It also works the other way=
 of course:=C2=A0=C2=A0 If a person wants to hear it, they will, which is j=
ust as subjectively bad, and can confound the researcher with all kinds of =
nonsensical results, strange messages, failed predictions, and so on.=C2=A0=
 Testing can be a way to better determine how to tell which methods and mes=
sages are the most valid and promising.

I certainly understand that some b=
eliefs are essentially religious faith: people state it is true, and don't =
want anyone to question it.=C2=A0 And I don't want to question anyone's rel=
igion (they get really mad and insulting when you do).

Maybe some people f=
eel that way about EVPs.=C2=A0 I feel that this technology is instead perfe=
ctly applicable to good testing.=C2=A0 There are many theories and approach=
es to EVP and ITC, and I think testing is the best way to determine which w=
orks the best, which equipment people should spend their money on, which th=
eories they should spend most time with.=C2=A0 I'm not sure why anyone woul=
d not want to determine these kinds of things.

But I am now in contact wit=
h the testers and with Karen, and will be happy to keep everyone informed o=
f how this all goes.=C2=A0 

Rj

--- On Sat, 1/2/10, Frank Sumption <purple=

m>

To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sa=
turday, January 2, 2010, 11:57 AM







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
=
      =C2=A0I don't mind the testing, but the concept of "objectively" test=
ing predisposes the interested parties to find the acceptable results. Thes=
e testers can't allow themselve to hear anything without fear of ridicule f=
rom the scientific community. The test would be biased, and I have no trust=
 in the scientist/debunker/ skeptic to do an honest test. This has been sho=
wn in all areas of paranormal research and the UFO fields. These profession=
al skeptics are not honest! Even I'm skeptical of huantings, as I don't thi=
nk there is such a thing as stuck spirit, but I am open to the evidence. 

=
=C2=A0
=C2=A0Enough said form me.
=C2=A0
=C2=A0Frank-S
, 

On Thu, Dec 31, =
2009 at 8:36 AM, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


=C2=A0 







What's wr=
ong with testing the box using a scientific methodology?

he was someone off the group and has an interest in EVP and the boxes.=C2=

a professional skeptic--wonder who pays these twits?

=C2=A0
=C2=A0
=C2=A0T=
hese skeptics don't allow themselves to hear anything, yet will proclaim th=
at as proof the boxes and EVP don't work, as if their hearing is somehow be=
tter than the average persons ear. If a person doesn't want to hear it, the=
y won't, and because they can''t hear EVP=C2=A0that means no one else an ei=
ther.=C2=A0 Yeah, real scientific!

=C2=A0
=C2=A0Gonna have to remember Goo=
gle-googel- google!!
